description: From Middle English so, swo, zuo, swa, swe, from Old English swā, swǣ, swē (“so, as, the same, such, that”), from Proto-West Germanic *swā, from Proto-Germanic *swa, *swē (“so”), from Proto-Indo-European *swē, *swō (reflexive pronomial stem). Cognate with Scots sae (“so”), West Frisian sa (“so”), Low German so (“so”), Dutch zo (“so”), German so (“so”), Danish så (“so”), Norwegian Nynorsk so, Swedish så ("so, such that"), Old Latin suad (“so”), Albanian sa (“how much, so, as”), Ancient Greek ὡς (hōs, “as”), Urdu سو‎ (sō, “hence”).

adjectives.description: so (comparative more so, superlative most so)

examples: You are responsible for this, is that not so?

entries.meaning: In that state or manner; with that attribute. A proadjective that replaces the aforementioned adjective phrase.
examples: If this separation was painful to all parties, it was most so to Martha.
It was so hot outside that all the plants died.
He was so good, they hired him on the spot.
I feel so much better now.
I so nearly lost my temper.
It’s not so bad. [i.e. it's acceptable]
But I so want to see the Queen when she visits our town!
Place the napkin on the table just so. If that's what you mean, then say so; (or do so).

entries.meaning: In the same manner or to the same extent as aforementioned; also.
examples: Just as you have the right to your free speech, so I have the right to mine.  Many people say she's the world's greatest athlete, but I don't think so.  "I can count backwards from one hundred." "So can I."

entries.meaning: (with as): To such an extent or degree; as.
examples: so far as;  so long as;  so much as

description: Shortened from sol, to make it an open syllable for uniformity with the rest of the scale.

entries.meaning: (music) A syllable used in solfège to represent the fifth note of a major scale.
(foods) A type of dairy product, made especially in Japan between the seventh and 10th centuries, by reducing milk by boiling it.
